Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>Thanks for the new graph.  I'm still a little confused about why the
>mean structure suddenly plummets at the start of each pruning phase? 
>Wouldn't you expect it to go down gradually as structure is removed
>bit by bit?  How could everything instantaneously become less complex
>(the way it looks in the graph)?  I'm probably misunderstanding
>something..
>  
>
There are a few factors to consider here. Firstly the drop isn't 
instantaneous in the strictest sense, the graph represents 32000 
generations performed over 90 minutes. Looking at the raw data I can 
tell you that the apparently near-instant drop in complexity typically 
takes about 200 generations. On the other hand it is very fast relative 
to the rate at which complexity is accumulated during complexification, 
this could be due to a couple fo factors. During pruning phase the 
genome selection routine changes slightly, so instead of sorting the 
population (actually each species) by fitness alone, I sort by fitness 
and then secondary sort on complexity, this therefore increases the 
selection pressure for smaller genomes. In addition the Simple-OCR 
problem domain is a very simple type of problem that relies almost 
entirely on making connections directly from inputs to outputs, and this 
(I would suggest) means that there are very few interdependencies 
between neurons and connections and this in turn means that it is far 
easier to remove accumulated redundant structure without having a 
detrimental effect. This idea ties in with some observations on other 
types of problem where the pruning phase is a lot less effective at 
removing structure.

To get a better feel for what is going on I would encourage you to do a 
quick run with the Simple-OCR domain and watch the 'best genome' window 
as the search passes through a pruning phase. You can literally watch 
the structure being stripped away within a matter of seconds.

Colin
